ygData.subject: Re: simple question
ygData.msgSnippet: ... think ... Okay...fair enough. ... Right...understood. ... Right...but if networks in your final generation contain redundant or unnecessary topology, then

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@c...> wrote:
> Jim and Derek (I am responding to your posting here too),
> I probably should have put a bit more time into my short little
> explanation because obviously I caused a lot of confusion, and I 
think
> probably it's unwarranted since we basically agree.

Okay...fair enough.

> My point was not that the final topology doesn't matter (it does), 
>but
> that it is not the *only* thing that matters.  

Right...understood.

> What I am saying is that, in contrast, it is important that *every*
> network you test over all of evolution should be as minimal as
> possible.  The reason for this is that it is easier to search in 
> small spaces.  

Right...but if networks in your final generation contain redundant 
or unnecessary topology, then those features have been accumulating 
throughout the search.  Thus, the search has been less efficient 
than it could have been, right?

> Search is the big deal here, i.e. can you find what you need in a
> practical amount of time?   For that, topology matters *throughout 
> the
> run*.  And not because a large topology takes more time to execute,
> but rather because a large topology means a high-dimensional search
> space, which means more search will be necessary. 

Well, both are an issue, aren't they?  And both are unwanted.  I 
fully understand that intermediate topologies are just as important 
as final ones.  The point is, it seems highly unlikely that if you 
have a network in the final generation that has 30% useless 
topology, that all that unnecessary topology was mutated in the last 
couple of generations.  It was accruing *throughout* the run, so 
this does affect the overall performance of the run.

So it seems to me that you can't logically separate the end result 
from the evolving topologies.  If there's waste at the end, there 
was waste throughout.

Derek
